markdownRemark.html:
Everyone who has spent some time working with git irremediably knows about merging. The merge command brings the changes carried out in a B branch (new-feature) to the main branch A (master). It does work fine when the A branch is not being modified. If no conflicts arise, new changes are added on top the A branch. The log reflects an incremental order of commits, or put in other words, the commits are shown in the same order were added. A timeline of changes.

* e13260a - (master) reset styles (52 minutes ago) <Enrique Arias>
* a1397e3 - added style file (59 minutes ago) <Enrique Arias>
* 2b6b5ca - new index content (2 hours ago) <Enrique Arias>
* 8fcdeae - added index.html (2 hours ago) <Enrique Arias>
| * 879b83e - (HEAD -> new-feature) New feature file (2 hours ago) <Enrique Arias>
| * 62de30d - New feature page (2 hours ago) <Enrique Arias>
| * d9ad32e - A new commit is introduced while previous changes are in stash (12 days ago) <Enrique Arias>
|/
* 13b16a5 - Revert "README updated" (2 weeks ago) <Enrique Arias>
* 76a1097 - Demo file updated (2 weeks ago) <Enrique Arias>
* a31e004 - README updated (2 weeks ago) <Enrique Arias>
* 44d4c5b - New README file (2 weeks ago) <Enrique Arias>
* ee42779 - New demo file (2 weeks ago) <Enrique Arias>
